isis.stitle: DT 466 / DT 530 Engine Diagnostic Manual for 4000 Series Trucks (2001) - SUPPLEMENTAL DIAGNOSTIC ANALYSIS - DIAGNOSING SCUFFED INJECTORS - Key-On Engine-Running Injector Test

svcproc.title: Key-On Engine-Running Injector Test
svcproc.para: The injector test is designed to detect problems with injection and combustion events. Performing a cylinder contribution test will analyze the individual contribution of each of the power cylinders. Its primary function is to detect a bad injector. The test will also detect problems that could affect the overall performance of the power cylinders (i.e.: valves, pushrods, pistons, rings, etc.).
During this test the ECM will control fuel delivery and determine each cylinder's power contribution. If a cylinder is not performing satisfactorily, a Diagnostic Trouble Code will be set.
Some of the key areas to examine on the graphical display of the cylinder contribution test are:

step1.para: When the test begins, the engine speed increases in increments up to 850 rpm.
The ECM increases fuel delivery to cylinder #1 (over-fuels) which causes engine speed to increase.
Fuel is reduced to remaining cylinders to maintain 850 rpm
The ECM decreases fuel delivery to cylinder #1 (under-fuels) which causes engine speed to decrease.
Fuel is increased to the remaining cylinders to maintain 850 rpm
At this point 2 key observations are noted:

item.para: The ECM compares fuel delivery of the remaining 5 cylinders during over-fuel condition
The ECM compares fuel delivery of remaining 5 cylinders during under-fuel condition

step1.para: If the difference is not what the ECM expects, a DTC is set for non-contributing cylinder. The procedure will repeat for the remaining cylinders until the test is complete.
The engine speed returns to low idle. The test is complete

note.para: During the cylinder contribution test, the fuel rate graph represents fuel delivery to the remaining 5 cylinders.

svcproc.para: The cylinder contribution test begins with cylinder #1 (front cylinder) and is performed sequentially. The rpm fluctuation on engines with more than one severely scuffed injector can be enough to stop the cylinder contribution test.
